cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. The Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all. Sigil, the City of Doors, floats above the Spire at the center of the Outlands, serving as the axle of the Great Wheel.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Vertical Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven; and an Underworld

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them, are the Inner Planes.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planeCategories.name: Special Planes
planeCategories.description: Unique planes that exist as distinct entities within the cosmology, such as the planar city of Sigil.

planes.name: Sigil, City of Doors
planes.philosophicalEssence: Sigil is a bustling planar metropolis holding countless portals to other planes and worlds, serving as a trader's paradise and hub of planar commerce and information.

physicalProperties.shape: Ring-shaped (torus); myriad structures built on the ring's inner surface. Creatures standing on one of Sigil's streets can see the city curve up over their heads and the far side of the city directly overhead.

timeFlow.description: No specific time flow alteration is described for Sigil in the source text.

requirement.description: Sigil is known as the City of Doors because it features an overwhelming number of item-keyed portals. The city sustains a brisk trade in information about the planes, particularly the commands or items required for the operation of particular portals.
requirement.keyItem: Various; each portal requires a specific item to function, acting much like a key to a door

portals.name: Portal to the Plain of Infinite Portals (Abyss Layer 1)

planarConnections.name: The Spire
planarConnections.description: At the center of the Outlands, like the axle of a great wheel, is the Spire, a needle-shaped mountain that rises high into the sky. Above this mountain's narrow peak, not part of the Outlands but a plane in its own right, floats the ring-shaped city of Sigil.

notableEntities.name: Lady of Pain
notableEntities.title: Ruler of Sigil
notableEntities.description: The inscrutable Lady of Pain, a being whose purpose and goals are unknown to even the sages of her city. She appears almost human, although she most definitely isn't. She wears ornate robes that shroud her body, and a mantle of blades coated in blue-green verdigris surrounds her masklike face. No one is certain who or what exactly the Lady of Pain is, but it's widely accepted she's a being on par with deities. Is Sigil her prison? Is she the fallen creator of the multiverse? No one knows—or if they do, they aren't telling.

civilizations.name: Sigil's Planar Trading Community
civilizations.description: Sigil is a trader's paradise. Goods and information come here from across the planes. The city sustains a brisk trade in information about the planes, particularly the commands or items required for the operation of particular portals.

specialRules.name: Independent Plane
specialRules.description: Sigil floats above the Spire at the center of the Outlands but is not part of the Outlands; it is a plane in its own right.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Sigil exists as a distinct plane of existence separate from the Outlands, despite its physical position above the Spire. It is a ring-shaped city with structures built on the inner surface, where gravity pulls toward the inner surface so that inhabitants can see the far side of the city directly overhead.

specialRules.name: Item-Keyed Portal Dominance
specialRules.description: Sigil features an overwhelming number of item-keyed portals. A traveler carrying a particular object can activate a portal; the item acts much like a key to a door. This item can be a common object or a particular one created for that portal.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Portals in Sigil function when the traveler carries a particular object that acts as a key. The city sustains a brisk trade in information about the commands or items required for the operation of particular portals.

adventureThemes: Intrigue involving the Lady of Pain

adventureSituations.situation: An item of legend is being sold at auction in Sigil, the City of Brass, or some other planar metropolis.

crossReferences.description: Sigil is referenced in the Planar Portals section as an example of item-keyed portal usage, in the Abyss Layer 1 description as a portal destination from the Plain of Infinite Portals, and in the Planar Adventure Situations table (entry 10).
The layers of the Abyss are numbered based on the sequence of their discovery and cataloging by explorers from Sigil.

globalPlanarConnections.name: Infinite Staircase
globalPlanarConnections.description: The Infinite Staircase is an extradimensional staircase that connects the planes. An entrance usually appears as a nondescript door. Beyond the portal lies a small landing with a stairway leading up and down. It changes appearance as it climbs and descends. It is home to Nafas, a noble genie created by the planar winds.

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Oceanus
globalPlanarConnections.description: The water of the Oceanus is sweet and fragrant, as befits its headwaters in the Blessed Fields of Elysium. It flows through each of Elysium's layers, passes through the top layer of the Beastlands, streams across the top layer of Arborea, and finally drains away somewhere in Arborea's second layer.

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Styx
globalPlanarConnections.description: The River Styx bubbles with grease, foul flotsam, and the putrid remains of battles along its banks. It churns through the top layers of Acheron, the Nine Hells, Gehenna, Hades, Carceri, the Abyss, and Pandemonium. Tributaries snake through lower layers of these planes.
hazards: Memory loss from contact with its waters
navigableBy: Sinister ferries crewed by Fiends or souls of the dead

globalPlanarConnections.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
globalPlanarConnections.description: The World Tree, Yggdrasil, is a cosmic ash tree that spans the Outer Planes and links them to many worlds of the Material Plane. Its roots stretch into the Lower Planes, touching Hades, Pandemonium, and possibly other Lower Planes. Most of its massive trunk rises through the plane of Ysgard, and its branches stretch through the Upper Planes and across the Astral to the Material Plane.

bloodWar.description: Throughout history, the teeming demon hordes of the Abyss and the regimented legions of devils from the Nine Hells have battled for supremacy in the cosmos. The Blood War is a conflict that has raged for millennia, ravaging the Lower Planes. The battlefields are concentrated in the Nine Hells and the Abyss, though fighting also takes place on the Material Plane, on the planes between those realms on the Great Wheel, and anywhere else demons and devils congregate.

factions.name: Demon Hordes
factions.role: Teeming chaotic hordes seeking to overwhelm through sheer numbers and ferocity

factions.name: Devil Legions
factions.role: Regimented legions fighting with discipline and infernal strategy

bloodWar.adventureImplications: Many demons and devils are obsessed with finding some advantage for their side in the Blood War, and powerful mortal adventurers are sometimes drawn into tangled schemes to that end. Natives of the Upper Planes also take steps to minimize the threat to the rest of the multiverse whenever the Blood War spills outside the Abyss and the Nine Hells.

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Portals
planarTravelMethods.description: A portal is a stationary, interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane to a specific location on another. Some portals function like doorways; others are locations that exist on multiple planes at once or flicker from one plane to another. Sigil, the City of Doors, features an overwhelming number of item-keyed portals.
requirements: Finding a portal that leads to the desired destination
Meeting the portal's activation requirement (command word, key item, random timing, situational condition, or time-based trigger)
risks: Most portals aren't open all the time

planarTravelMethods.name: Gate Spell
planarTravelMethods.description: The Gate spell can directly transport adventurers to any other plane with precision.
requirements: Ability to cast the Gate spell

planarTravelMethods.name: Plane Shift Spell
planarTravelMethods.description: Plane Shift can directly transport adventurers to any other plane, with varying degrees of precision.
requirements: Tuning fork attuned to the destination plane

planarTravelMethods.name: Etherealness Spell
planarTravelMethods.description: Etherealness allows adventurers to enter the Ethereal Plane.

planarTravelMethods.name: Astral Projection Spell
planarTravelMethods.description: Astral Projection lets adventurers project themselves into the Astral Plane and from there travel to the Outer Planes.
risks: Ether cyclones in the Ethereal Plane

planarAdventureSituations.situation: When magic fails to revive a dead person, the only solution is to venture to the Outer Planes to find the person's spirit and either release it from some prison or convince the person to return to life.

People who venture into the woods keep accidentally wandering into the Feywild or the Shadowfell. They might never return, return with no sense of how much time has passed, or return dramatically changed.
A long-dead oracle is the only one who knows how a terrible prophecy might be averted, but the cataclysmic fulfillment of the prophecy has already begun.
A god has stopped answering prayers and won't respond to any Commune spell.
A devil has tricked an angel into meddling in the Blood War, and the angel seeks mortal aid.
An ancestor of one of the characters must be convinced to bless the character before the full power of the character's bloodline can be unleashed.
A foolhardy knight carried a holy weapon on a doomed mission into the Nine Hells, and the powers of Mount Celestia want the weapon and the knight's remains retrieved.
A titan is imprisoned on an Outer Plane. The characters might be trying to stop those who seek to release it, or they might want to release it to help defend the world from a greater threat.

To prove themselves worthy of an even greater quest, the characters are sent to slay a horrible monster, win the favor of a powerful planar being, negotiate peace between two warring planar factions, or retrieve a long-lost item on another plane.
An item of legend is being sold at auction in Sigil, the City of Brass, or some other planar metropolis.

globalPlanarDissonance.description: Celestials who visit the Lower Planes and Fiends who visit the Upper Planes experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to its nature, a Celestial or Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to the creature's nature

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: Each failed save adds another 1d4 subtraction to all D20 Tests

onSuccess.description: The creature resists the planar dissonance for this Long Rest period.

recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
